jeopardy_round: 5 PEOPLE WHO'VE NEVER BEEN IN MY KITCHEN

(5, 1).clue: This 18th c. line & its extensions westward became the boundary between Northern & Southern states

(6, 1).clue: This bird rearranges its eggs in the sand--hence the belief it's burying its head

(1, 2).clue: As in this clue, ending a sentence with one of these is a practice some don't agree with

(2, 2).clue: 1961:"Fat man, you shoot a great game of pool.""So do you, Fast Eddie"

(3, 2).clue: I'm kickin' it island-style in these geographically named shorts I sport here

(4, 2).clue: Known as the "White Mouse", New Zealand spy Nancy Wake was the Allies' most decorated woman in this war

(5, 2).clue: The Yamanote Line, this city's busiest train line, carries more than 3.5 million people a day

(6, 2).clue: This fanged, hairy spider of the Southwest desert can live up to 30 years

(1, 3).clue: "As the sun set" is known as a "sentence" this

(2, 3).clue: 1979:"This is Ripley, last survivor of the Nostromo, signing off.  Come on, Cat"

(3, 3).clue: Hey, there, Daddy-O--it's the rhymin' name of the threads I'm stylin' here

(4, 3).clue: On April 9,  2005 England celebrated the happy nuptials of Prince Charles & this woman

(5, 3).clue: In the 1930s Germany built fortifications called the Siegfried Line on the west side of this river

(6, 3).clue: The name of this wild canine now found across the U.S. comes from an Aztec word

(1, 4).clue: As necessary to complete the idea, the last 3 words of "I like men who bake bread" form a restrictive type of this

(2, 4).clue: 1975:"I used to hate the water.""I can't imagine why"

(3, 4).clue: It's the '70s casual attire I'm in here--I burned all the real pics of me in one

(5, 4).clue: The Curzon Line, proposed in 1919, became essentially the boundary between Poland & this country in 1945

(6, 4).clue: Russian thistle is also called this, since the plant detaches from its base & scatters seeds as it rolls

(1, 5).clue: It's best to use this type of voice when possible; "Bob ate the pie" is good... "The pie was eaten by Bob", not so much

(2, 5).clue: 1968:"Boys, let's watch the cigarette butts, shall we?  This is my house, not a pigsty"

(3, 5).clue: I think this '50s fashion seen here  looks good on me--hey, who are you to judge?

(4, 5).clue: Alois is the middle name of this current U.S. governor

(5, 5).clue: In 1949 Israel & Jordan created the Green Line between them, determining the boundary of this troubled area

(6, 5).clue: This desert insect was part of Egyptian cosmogony; it was the Sun, & its rolled food was the Earth

(1, 1).clue: He made recordings reading from some of his own works, including "Poems and Songs of Middle-earth"

(2, 1).clue: Despite her name, this woman who replaced Kim Hill in the Black Eyed Peas has never been married to Prince Andrew

(3, 1).clue: To honor peace, Jean Verame painted some 4 mi. of Sinai Desert boulders blue; this intl. org. donated the paint

(2, 2).clue: The 2008 "American Idol" finale featured a medley of his hits, including "Father Figure"

(3, 2).clue: Damien Hirst decorated a cast of a skull with 8,601 of these gems & sold the darn thing for $100 million

(6, 2).clue: This classic from 1939 features a load of Joads, including Ma, Pa & Tom

(6, 4).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew waves a reflective stick through a projected image.)  Even when a projected image appears to be gone, you can still see it when I wave this stick because of this phenomenon in which the light detectors in the eye send signals to the brain

(1, 5).clue: His short story "Rain" was inspired by a missionary & a prostitute who were passengers aboard his ship on a trip to Samoa

(2, 5).clue: "I don't wanna be a loser", cried this girl singer in 1964; well, it's her party

(4, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew holds a vintage electronics product at Sony Headquarters in Tokyo, Japan.) When it was launched in 1979, this Sony product was to have a different name in each country, like the "Soundabout" in the U.S. & the "Stowaway" in England

(6, 5).clue: In 1950 Scottish nationalists stole this object from under the coronation chair at Westminster Abbey
